Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Mechanisms Underlying Discrimination in the Labor Market

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1602541
Stephen Benard
Trenton D. Mize
Indiana University

Despite an increase in some legal rights and acceptance of same-sex relationships, gay men and lesbian women continue to face disadvantages in the labor market. Gay men earn less than comparable heterosexual men, and studies have shown that both gay men and lesbian women face hiring discrimination. Despite these initial studies establishing labor market inequalities for gay men and lesbian women, there remains little evidence to explain why the disadvantages exist. Multiple competing explanations exist, including: (a) disadvantaging stereotypes that link sexual orientation with assumptions of competence and ability, (b) stereotypes of gay men and lesbian women as less masculine/feminine than heterosexual men and women, and (c) a society and labor market that have preferences for traditional masculine behavior in high status occupations and leadership positions.

The investigator will complete two laboratory studies, two survey experiments, and a test with nationally representative survey data to examine hiring discrimination and the mechanisms underlying unequal treatment. Study 1 tests for hiring discrimination in entry-level jobs using both a controlled laboratory experiment and a survey experiment in a diverse sample. Study 2 examines hiring discrimination for positions of senior leadership using a controlled laboratory study and a survey experiment in a diverse sample. Study 3 uses nationally representative survey data to examine the existing patterns of labor market inequalities. The experimental studies provide key causal evidence of discrimination and the ability to test for underlying mechanisms, while the survey data provides generalizable and representative evidence. The project will provide key evidence to help address existing inequalities and will also serve as a training site for student research assistants who will learn experimental research techniques and methodology while working on the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Despite years of research on gender inequalities — and increasing academic work examining sexual orientation — fundamental questions about the intersecting nature of sex, gender, and sexual orientation remain. In this dissertation, I examine the overlapping factors of (a) sex categories, (b) stereotypes of masculinity and femininity, and (c) sexual orientation categories. I propose three competing theoretical models to explain how these factors influence labor market outcomes. In three empirical studies I examine how these factors influence hiring decisions and how they pattern existing labor market inequalities.

In two experimental studies — one laboratory study and one online survey experiment — I test for the causal influence of sex category, gendered behavior, and sexual orientation on hiring decisions. The survey experiment is conducted in a diverse national sample of hiring managers to determine how factors such as the age, education, and labor market experience of an evaluator impacts assessments. The findings suggest that gendered behavior — here, the extent to which the job applicants displayed stereotypically masculine or feminine traits — is the primary factor influencing perceptions of competence, likeability, and hostility for job candidates. That is, while sex
and sexual orientation influence competence and likeability assumptions, they do so largely through their association with gender stereotypes. However, there are also important intersectional considerations, with the effect of gendered behavior sometimes differing depending on the job applicant’s sex and sexual orientation category — and also based on the sex category of the evaluator. That is, men and women evaluators preference different traits when evaluating job applicants and often make different recommendations about what types of candidates they think should be hired.

Using data from a representative survey of young adults, I show that sexual orientation also patterns earnings and perceived discrimination. Masculinity and femininity further serve to pattern perceived discrimination, but has less association with earnings. I close with a discussion of the implications of the findings for organizations and with prescriptions for making the hiring process more equitable and efficient for all parties involved.
